intro: Campuloclinium campuloclinioides, commonly known as the Florida false nettle, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the southeastern United States. It typically grows in wetlands, marshes, and along the edges of ponds, thriving in moist, sandy soils. The plant features opposite, heart-shaped leaves with a hairy texture and small, inconspicuous greenish-white flowers that appear in clusters. Its stems are often covered in fine hairs and can grow up to 1 meter in height. The plant is known for its ability to tolerate periodic flooding, making it an important component of wetland ecosystems.
